title: SMT201 Group 5
text:
Welcome to Derna EvacuConnect!
Our project revolves around the theme of GIS-based Accessibility Analysis and Mapping of Emergency Evacuation Centres and Medical Services of Derna City, Libya.


On Sunday, 10 September 2023‚Ä¶
Storm Daniel, the deadliest Medicane (Mediterranean Tropical Storm) hit Libya. The rain it brought pushed two dams in the Derna district of Libya to their limits, causing their collapse, leading to a massive flood that led to large-scale damage and destruction of buildings and infrastructure with thousands of casualties.

Below shows parts of Derna City, Libya before and after of the flood.






  
    
    Before
  
  
    
    After
  






Casualty from disasters is tragic.
Evacuation Centres and Medical facilities exist to mitigate its impact, yet any disaster has the potential to reduce their effectiveness.



This motivates us to analyse and assess:

The accessibility of Derna City‚Äôs evacuation centres and medical services.
How disaster-proof and accessible Derna‚Äôs Evacuation Centres and Medical Facilities are.






Data Preparation

Buildings are used as an approximation of Derna‚Äôs Residences in the network analysis.

Relevant Flood extent, Buildings, Roads, Evacuation Centres & Medical Facilities data are extracted.

Data Pre- & Post-Flooding are verified through high-resolution satellite images.

Layers are clipped to the study area & saved with the correct Libyan Projected Coordinates System (EPSG:3197).

Centroids for Buildings, Evacuation Centres and Medical Facilities are created.

Accessibility Analysis

QNEAT3 Plugin in QGIS, Network Analysis Toolbox utility Iso-Areas as Polygons (from Layer) are used to measure the accessibility of buildings to the Evacuation Centres & Medical Facilities.

Visualising Data

To easily visualise accessibility, categorised polygons with color ramps representing accessibility were created.
We also used various geoprocessing tools like merge and dissolve, to group common data together for a more comprehensive finding.





Overall, we found that Derna‚Äôs Evacuation Centres and Medical Facilities are not very disaster-proof and accessibility decreases by a huge proportion even though only a small area of Derna City was destroyed by Storm Daniel.
Find out more in our poster and/or report!

title: Results & Discussion
text:
Analysis & Discussion

 

The pre-flood maps below are satellite imagery of Derna City on 01 July 2023 and 13 September 2023 for post-flood (within 3 days of flood occurrence).

Road network





  
    
    Pre-flood
  
  
    
    Post-flood
  

Road networks connecting the East and West of Derna City was completely cut off as the massive flood waters destroyed the road networks near the river, evident from the satellite imagery. This would likely reduced the accessibility of evacuation centres and medical facilities between the East from the West part of Derna City.


Buildings





  
    
    Pre-flood
  
  
    
    Post-flood
  

Many buildings near the river and north part of Derna City are completely destroyed after the flood. Evident from the amount of bare land observed from the satellite imagery post-flood as compared to pre-flood. Derna City‚Äôs accessibility to emergency facilities especially in these areas would be very important.


Accessibility to Evacuation Centres





  
    
    Pre-flood
  
  
    
    Post-flood
  




Access between the East and West of Derna City was completely cut off as the massive flood waters destroyed the bridges connecting both sides, also observed in the loss of road network. This reduced the overall accessibility of evacuation centres between the East and the West part of Derna City. From the accessibility map, initially, areas surrounding the river was within 1km from an evacuation centre. However, after the flood, it is no longer accessible due to the destroyed bridges which are part of Derna City‚Äôs road network.
From the table, we can also observe that around 40% of the building that were present are either destroyed, or became inaccessible to evacuation centres after the flood.


Accessibility to Medical Facilities





  
    
    Pre-flood
  
  
    
    Post-flood
  




From the accessibility map, even with the dam being about 1.5km away from two medical facilities, the region surrounding the dam is totally inaccessible after the flood due to the loss in road network within the area.
From the table, we can also observe that there is almost an aggregate of 40% loss of Derna City‚Äôs building‚Äôs accessibility to medical facilities, with the buildings either being destroyed or becoming isolated due to the flood that occurred, which is not ideal in such massive disaster.

Project Motivation & Objectives

Motivation
Casualties from disasters are tragic. Evacuation Centres & Medical facilities exist to mitigate its impact, yet any disaster has the potential to reduce their effectiveness. Considering the high casualty count in the case of the flood of Derna City in September 2023, we decided to analyse and assess the accessibility of Derna City‚Äôs evacuation centres and medical services to evaluate the changes in the extent of such facilities effectiveness in rendering aid and medical services in an aftermath of a disaster such as the flood.


Objectives
Based on our motivation, we have 3 main objective for our project:

To find out the accessibility of Derna city‚Äôs evacuation centres and medical services.
To find out how disaster-proof the accessibility to the evacuation centres and medical services are.
To determine if accessibility of these facilities are the main cause of high death and missing toll.

title: Lessons Learnt
text:
While efforts can be made to limit the impact of a disaster, the true scale of any disaster is difficult to predict, as per the case of Derna city where the flood was so devastating due to immense volume of water released from the burst dams.
It is important to diversify the locations of evacuation centres and medical services so that the impact of any disaster regardless of scale would not completely obliterate a city‚Äôs emergency capabilities.
A clear lesson is that areas near water bodies such as rivers are often the most prone the heaviest flood damage. As such, evacuation centres and medical services should be situated a safe distance near such areas to further disaster proof of emergency facilities.

title: Results & Discussion
text:
Results & Conclusion

Results
State of Buildings

From our GIS analysis, both evacuation centres and medical facilities‚Äô accessibility show a significant and drastic drop, especially in areas near the river.
Our findings are further backed by our tabular data showing a fall in the service quantity of both evacuation centres and medical facilities. The drop in service quantity is due to buildings either being completely destroyed or becoming isolated from any existing road networks.

Drop in Accessibility

A small area concentrated within the flood extent near the river had their accessibility to evacuation centres and medical facilities compromised. Yet despite its small area, its led to almost a 40% decrease in accessibility of these places, across the entirety of Derna City.

Need for Reinforced Infrastructures

From this finding, we can safely conclude that the bridges that were destroyed due to the flood played a significant role in affecting accessibility. In order for the accessibility to such emergency facilities to be more disaster proof, Libya would need to ensure that the road network, especially the bridges, are able to better withstand such disasters.
With the same findings, considerations can be made to focus on the need to repair and reconnect the road networks between the East & West of Derna City for a more effective and efficient emergency response. This could help lower any further loss of life.



Conclusion
While emergency facilities (evacuation centres and medical facilities) should ideally be accessible to all, there will undoubtedly be areas with better and poorer accessibility due to their relative distance from such centres and facilities. However, through usage of GIS software, severely underserved areas can be better identified, and improvements in accessibility to such areas can be made.
